Expectation1: Diagnose patient illnesses accurately based on symptoms and tests
Situation1: A patient with symptoms of the common cold has come in for a routine check-up.
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: During a street demonstration, someone urges them to step past a barricade onto restricted city property.
Story:
I sat in my clinic, listening to the patient describe her sore throat and runny nose. As a doctor, I knew I had to be thorough—ask the right questions, order the right tests, make sure I didn’t miss anything serious. My mind was focused on her symptoms, the subtle differences between a harmless cold and something more severe. But outside, the city was alive with noise. The demonstration I’d planned to join as a citizen was in full swing. I’d promised myself I would stand up for what I believed in, respect the rights of others, and follow the law. 

After my shift, I hurried to the protest, still thinking about my patient’s case. The crowd surged, and someone beside me urged, “Come on, let’s step past the barricade—make them listen!” My heart pounded. As a citizen, I wanted to be heard, to fight for justice. But the barricade was there for a reason, and crossing it would break the law. I felt the weight of my white coat, the trust my patients placed in me, and the responsibility to set an example. I stood at the edge, torn between my duty as a doctor and my convictions as a citizen, unsure which path to take.
